title: The Police under Public Scrutiny - Experiences, Perceptions, and Reactions to a Public Service Institution 1982-2003
abstractText:
In the last three decades, the police forces in England and Wales have been subject to a series of reforms designed to increase efficiency in policing and crime reduction and to improve public attitudes towards the police. The research evaluates the impact of these reforms on the public's perceptions of the police and on public-police contact, using data from the British Crime Surveys (BCS) conducted between 1982 and 2003. The BCS records the opinions and victimisation risks of a representative sample of the population in England and Wales, including details about crimes that respondents might have experienced.

More specifically, the study explores:

  • public perceptions of the effectiveness of police and local safety interventions, such as police advice to victims, call responses times and the presence of neighbourhood watch schemes;
  • the relationship between victims and non-victims' perceptions of crime, safety and policing;
  • the link between changes in the perception and the experience of crime, and reforms to the operations and the organisation of police forces in individual Police Force Areas;
  • and patterns of crime reporting, in particular changes in the type or severity of incidents reported to the police.
